awd_titl_txt: TC: Small: Towards precise specification of logic-based acces-control policies
awd_abstract_narration:
Today's computing environments are characterized by an ongoing dramatic increase in connectivity and data sharing. A critical concern in this setting is access control---the ability to easily and quickly allow access to authorized users or devices, while preventing misuse, unauthorized access, and violations of privacy.  Two common pitfalls in many approaches to access control are (1) their inability to support highly flexible access-control policies while avoiding unintended side effects and (2) difficulty in usefully differentiating between all the authority that a user might need and the minimal authority that she requires to perform a specific task.  Both these shortcomings prevent systems from enforcing exactly the policies that users desire and thereby increase the danger of misuse and the costs of compromise.

This award supports the design and implementation of mechanisms that make it possible to specify and enforce security policies that more precisely limit the amount of authority that is conveyed to users or devices.  More specifically, new mechanisms will be developed to enable restricting the circumstances under which the authority to access a resource can be used, and to allow administrators to specify these restrictions as constraints on policies.  At the same time, new methods will be developed to distinguish between the total authority that is conveyed to a user and the subset of that authority that she may exercise at a specific moment.  These improvements will be carried out in the context of logic-based access control, an approach that offers significant benefits in terms of flexibility and assurance of correctness.

por.por_cntn:
The least privilege principle dictates that a software module or a component of a distributed system have only the minimal privileges needed to perform its intended function. This principle is often only loosely followed in the design and use of computer systems, leaving the door open to preventable misuses and vulnerabilities.


This project furthered the development of two technologies that enable the privileges of components of software systems to be more precisely controlled: logic-based access control and information-flow control. Both technologies allow security policy to be specified declaratively, clearly separating the specification of a policy fromits enforcement and making it easier to correctly specify policies. Both technologies are amenable to rigorous formal analysis, which can be used to verify the correctness of the design of an enforcement system and provide strong guarantees that enforcement decisions made in practice are consistent with desired policies.

In the space of logic-based access control, this project developed techniques to restrict the circumstances under which the authority to access a resource can be used and to allow administrators to specify these restrictions as constraints on policies. It also made it possible to distinguish between the total authority that is conveyed to a user and the subset of that authority that she may exercise at a specific moment.

In the space of information-flow control, this project, in combinations with other projects on related topics, helped develop techniques to lower the risk of information leaks and other attacks that have been shown to plague Android devices and web browsers. In particular, results from the project extend previous research on information-flow control to provide strong, formally verifiable, flexible protection mechanisms that can enforce a range of practically useful policies on Android devices and on web browsers without interfering with the intended functionality of these systems.

The research advances enabled by this project address the security of computer systems that most computer users utilize on a daily basis. Results from the project have spawned several follow-up projects and interaction with industry. The project also provided training for several undergraduate and graduate students, including several from underrepresented groups.
